Subject: Bicycle touring -- Asia|~|Bicycle touring -- Greece
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Collection 1841
Description.abstract: William Lewis Sachtleben was an American long-distance cyclist who rode across Asia from Istanbul to Peking in 1891 to 1892 with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr., his classmate from Washington University. Their journey had actually begun the day after they graduated from college, when they travelled to New York and on to Liverpool. In all they travelled 15,044 miles by bicycle, “the longest continuous land journey ever made around the world” as reported in their book Across Asia on a bicycle (1895). This collection consists of photographs taken in 1891 covering their winter stay in Athens and part of the journey that followed from Istanbul to Tashkent. The circular format photographs were taken with a Kodak box camera which was one of the first cameras available to amateur photographers (the Kodak, the No. 1, or the No. 2).
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.

Name.subject: Rhomaides, Konstantinos, d. 1900?|~|Rhomaides, Aristotelis, d. 1916?|~|Allen, Thomas Gaskell|~|Gurdjian, Serope A. (Serope Armenag), b. 1847
Title: Thomas Allen, Serope Gurdjian, and the photographers Aristotelis and Konstantinos Rhomaides on a city street, Athens, 1891
Description.note: Photograph of, L to R, Thomas Allen, Serope Gurdjian, and the two brothers Aristotelis and Konstantinos Rhomaides (photographers specializing in the documentation of archeological sites) on a narrow street in Athens, perhaps near the Rhomaides' atelier (listed in 1907 as "3 Place de la Constitution" which is now Constitution Square, or Syntagma Square).|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|Serope Armenag Gurdjian was an Armenian from Turkey who became a naturalized U.S. citizen and earned a college degree from Bowdoin College in 1877. Having been detained in Istanbul in October 1890 on suspicion of participating in a revolutionary committee, he was released based on his U.S. citizenship and then traveled to Athens, where he met and befriended William Sachtleben and Thomas Allen.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: No. 11. Jan. 10, 1891. A view of the large and splendid Ateliers of Romaides [sic] in Athens. The two brothers, Romaides, Gurdjian, and Allen. An interior view time exposure.

Title: William Sachtleben examining the grave relief of Demetria and Pamphile, Athens, 1891
Description.note: Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|Photograph of William Lewis Sachtleben  examining the marble grave relief (stele) of Demetria and Pamphile (ca. 325-310 BC.) at the ancient cemetery of Kerameikos in Athens. Sachtleben leans against the monument as he reaches to touch the leg of the throne of Pamphile with his right hand;  his bicycle rests against his side. He holds a small book in his left hand and another open book rests on the base of the monument. Ancient ruins are visible in the landscape beyond.|~|The stele of Demetria and Pamphile is in the Kerameikos Museum (Archaiologiko Mouseio Kerameikou) in Athens.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: No. 31 [or 39]. Jan. 15, 1891. The tomb stone of Demetria and Pamphile, two Athenian maidens. Recently excavated in west Athens among the ruins of the Street of Tombs.

Description.note: Photograph of William Lewis Sachtleben  standing next to a Roman sarcophagus in the Kerameikos area. Sachtleben is standing behind his bicycle and appears to be writing in a small book.|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|The Roman period sarcophagus probably dates to the later second century CE, and was found near the Dipylon Gate. It is now at the Kerameikos Museum (Archaiologiko Mouseio Kerameikou) in Athens.

Title: William Sachtleben at the Stoa of the Giants in the Agora, Athens, 1891
Description.note: The center of the Agora was open until a theater was build there, called the Odeion of Agrippa. It was destroyed by fire in A.D. 267 and in about A.D. 400 the Stoa of the Giants (also known at the Palace of the Giants or the Gymnasium) was built using the colossal Giant and Triton statues from the debris of the Odeion of Agrippa on its north side.|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|Photograph of William Lewis Sachtleben at the Stoa of the Giants in the Agora in Athens, in front of three of the colossal figures of Giants and Tritons on pedestals. Sachtleben stands next to his bicycle and seven or so small children are behind him looking toward him. Two houses can be seen in the background.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: No. 3. Jan. 1891. A general view taken in the Stoa of the Giants.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Name.subject: Sultanahmet Camii (Istanbul, Turkey)|~|Obelisk of Thutmose III (Istanbul, Turkey)|~|Allen, Thomas Gaskell|~|Hippodrome of Constantinople (Istanbul, Turkey)
Title: Thomas Allen next to the Serpent Column and in front of the Obelisk of Thutmose III at the Hippodrome, Istanbul, 1891
Description.note: Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|View of Thomas Allen standing next to his Humber bicycle in the Hippodrome of Constantinople (Sultanahmet Meydanı) as 2 other men walk by. He is standing next to a circular iron fence within which is the Serpent Column (or Delphi Tripod or Plataean Tripod), an ancient bronze column originally part of an ancient Greek Sacrificial tripod in Delphi. A wall and minaret of the Sultanahmet Camii (Mosque of Sultan Ahmet I) is on the right and in the background on the left is the Egyptian Obelisk of Thutmose III (Thutmosis), sometimes called the Obelisk of Theodosius.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Handwritten on negative: 105 / 20|~|Text from negative sleeve: No. 17. March 21, 1891. The serpent column, or Column of Pharoah, King of Egypt. Old Roman remains in Stanbul.

Subject: Bicycle touring -- Asia|~|Tombs & sepulchral monuments -- Turkey -- Istanbul
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Name.subject: Tomb of Sultan Mahmud II (Istanbul, Turkey)|~|Allen, Thomas Gaskell
Title: Thomas Allen  with his bicycle at the Tomb of Sultan Mahmud II, Istanbul, 1891
Description.note: The tomb of Sultan Mahmud II (reg. 1808-1839) was built in 1840 by the sultan's son Abdulmecid. The mausoleum was constructed in the then-popular Ottoman Empire style, one influenced by the neoclassical, Napoleonic French Empire style. It is located Divanyolu Street, Çemberlitas Neighborhood of Eminönü District.|~|View of Thomas Allen standing on an unpaved street outside of the Tomb of Sultan Mahmud II (II. Mahmud Türbesi ve Sebili). A carriage is on the road in the background  and eight men and five dogs are on the sidewalk.|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: No. 18. March 21, 1891. The tomb of Sultan Mahmud in Stanbul. The Turkish canines.|~|Handwritten on negative: 105 / 21

Title: Surp Krikor Lusavoriç Ermeni Kilisesi (Church of Saint Gregory the Illuminator), main entrance, Kayseri, Turkey, 1891
Description.note: Surp Krikor Lusavoriç Ermeni Kilisesi (Saint Gregory the Illuminator or Saint Gregory the Enlightener) is an Armenian church that was constructed in 1856, probably on the site of a previous older church. It remains the only operating Armenian church in eastern Anatolia. It is located at Cafer Bey Mah. Topaç Sok. No:5, Hürriyet, Melikgazi, Kayseri.|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|View of the main west entrance porch of Surp Krikor Lusavoriç Ermeni Kilisesi beneath the bell tower. Six people can be seen walking towards the entrance.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

Title: Iranian man repairing a wagon wheel near "Dilusan," Khoy vicinity, Iran, 1891
Description.note: Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|Photograph of an Iranian man standing between 2 huge wagon wheels on a road near "Dilusan," in the vicinity of Khoy, with William Sachtleben with his Humber bicycle on the left, a little boy behind him and others visible behind the wheel on the right.|~|This photograph appears with the caption "A Persian Repairing the Wheels of His Wagon" in the book by Thomas Allen and William Sachtleben, Across Asia on a Bicycle (1897), p. 94.

Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: No. 3. July 12, 1891. Scene on the road near Dilusan. A Persian repairing his huge wagon wheels, large and heavy enough for an enormous weight. The primitive wagon.

Subject: Bicycle touring -- Asia|~|Gates $x Iranian -- Qazvin
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Gateway entering Qazvin from the west, Qazvīn, Iran, 1891
Description.note: During the 9th century A.D. seven gates made entrance to the city possible. In Qajar period there existed nine gates surrounding the city which were connected to each other through a wall around the city. These gates (darvāzeh in Persian) were: Panbeh Riseh,  Sheikh Abad, Rasht, Maghlävak, Khandaghbar, Shahzadeh Hossein, Mossala, Tehran, Räh e Koushk. Due to 20th century urban expansion, unfortunately only the last two gates remain standing.|~|View of the gateway entering Qazvin from the west.|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

Title: William Sachtleben, Thomas Allen, Basilios Kapsambelis and 2 Greek men in front of the Parthenon, Athens, 1891
Description.note: Basilios Georgiou Kapsambelis was Chief Quartermaster of the Royal Navy in Greece;  he was also president of the "Piraeus Cycling Association".|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|View of, from L to R, William Sachtleben, wearing a cap, Thomas Allen, wearing a fez or tarboush type hat, Basilios Kapsambelis (probably), wearing a bowler hat, and 2 Greek men in traditional dress on the Acropolis in front of the Parthenon. Sachtleben and Allen stand next to their Humber bicycles. The 2 men on the right each wear a white pleated foustanella, white socks and pointed shoes called tsarouhia.

Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Panoramic view of Lycabettus and the city of Athens, looking northeast, 1891
Description.note: Mount Lycabettus, also known as Lycabettos, Lykabettos or Lykavittos (Greek: Λυκαβηττός, pronounced [likaviˈtos]), is a Cretaceous limestone hill in Athens, Greece. At 277 meters (908 feet) above sea level, the hill is the highest point in the city that surrounds it. Pine trees cover its base, and at its two peaks are the 19th century Chapel of St. George, a theatre, and a restaurant [Wikipedia].|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.

Description.note: View of Serope Gurdjian standing on Roman mosaic pavement at the Library of Hadrian. William Sachtleben's bicycle is parked next to him.|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|Serope Armenag Gurdjian was an Armenian from Turkey who became a naturalized U.S. citizen and earned a college degree from Bowdoin College in 1877. Having been detained in Istanbul in October 1890 on suspicion of participating in a revolutionary committee, he was released based on his U.S. citizenship and then traveled to Athens, where he met and befriended William Sachtleben and Thomas Allen.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: No. 19. Feb. 24, 1891. Among the ruins in the Stoa of Hadrian. Gurdjian and the bicycle.

Subject: Bicycle touring -- Greece|~|Springs -- Greece -- Athens
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Name.subject: Sachtleben, William Lewis
Title: William Sachtleben at the spring Kallirrhóē, probably south of the Olympieion, Athens, 1891
Description.note: William Sachtleben standing next to his bicycle at the spring Kallirrhóē, probably in an area south of the Olympieion. Water issues from a narrow channel in the rock into a pool.|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's stay in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.|~|This is probably the spring described in the 1894 Baedeker guide (pg. 51): "To the S. of the Olympieion runs the bed of the Ilissos (p. 49), with the remains of a wharf or quay. The polished surface of a ridge of rock that crosses the stream here also seems to betray the action of water at a former period. To the S. is the Chapel of St. Photini, a visit to which is amply repaid by the fine view of the Acropolis and the Olympieion. Below, on the margin of the Ilissos, the spring of Kallirhoë (Pl. F, 8) issues from the rock and is still called Kallirói ('pleasantly flowing'). Narrow channels in the rock originally supplied it more abundantly with water."
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Text from negative sleeve: No. 44. March 7, 1891. The spring Kallirhoe, (pleasantly flowing). This is the old spring frequented by the Athenian maidens who carried away the crystal waters

Subject: Carts & wagons $x Turkish -- Turkey -- Bursa|~|Bridges -- Turkey -- Bursa
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library Special Collections
Title: Bridge of Merab Kuprü, Bursa, Turkey, 1895
Description.note: View of a covered wagon pulled by a horse  on a stone bridge supported by a row of  arches. A shadow, probably of William Sachtleben as he takes the photograph, is visible in the foreground.|~|The handwritten list of images may be seen on the image with ark no. 21198/zz002hftdx|~|This photograph was most probably taken in 1895, when William Sachtleben was in Turkey to investigate the disappearance of cyclist Frank Lenz who had last been seen near Erzurum. Notes accompanying negatives indicate that during this trip, Sachtleben was in Bursa and travelled from Trabzon to Erzurum. Sachtleben's 1891 photographs of his bicycle tour across Asia have a circular format.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Caption from list: 10. Bridge of Merab (Merab Kuprü)

Behind it is a wagon pulled by 2 horses and the domes of a mosque are visible in the distance.|~|This photograph was most probably taken in 1895, when William Sachtleben was in Turkey to investigate the disappearance of cyclist Frank Lenz who had last been seen near Erzurum. Notes accompanying negatives indicate that during this trip, Sachtleben was in Bursa and travelled from Trabzon to Erzurum. Sachtleben's 1891 photographs of his bicycle tour across Asia have a circular format.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Caption from list: 9. A Broussa native carriage

Subject: Carriages & coaches $x Turkish -- Turkey -- Bursa|~|Dwellings -- Turkey -- Bursa|~|Horses -- Turkey -- Bursa
Name.repository: University of California, Los Angeles. $b Library. $b Dept. of Special Collections
Title: Man walking on a street with a house and cart and house behind him, Bursa, Turkey, 1895
Description.note: A list of images handwritten by William Sachtleben may contain a reference to this image in entry number 11 (see image ark no. 21198/zz002j5crn).|~|This photograph was most probably taken in 1895, when William Sachtleben was in Turkey to investigate the disappearance of cyclist Frank Lenz who had last been seen near Erzurum. Notes accompanying negatives indicate that during this trip, Sachtleben was in Bursa and travelled from Trabzon to Erzurum. Sachtleben's 1891 photographs of his bicycle tour across Asia have a circular format.|~|View of a Turkish man, possibly a coachman, walking across a street towards the photographer, with a horse and cart behind him in front of a house.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Caption from image list: A Broussa coachman rushing up to me for a job (see image ark no. 21198/zz002j5crn).

Title: Wooden bridge leading towards ruins and a house, Turkey, 1895

Title: Turkish people in a town, Turkey, 1895

A woman wearing a light colored veil around her head and torso stands beneath an umbrella with her son, wearing a fez hat, and daughter. Description.note: This photograph was most probably taken in 1895, when William Sachtleben was in Turkey to investigate the disappearance of cyclist Frank Lenz who had last been seen near Erzurum. Notes accompanying negatives indicate that during this trip, Sachtleben was in Bursa and travelled from Trabzon to Erzurum. Sachtleben's 1891 photographs of his bicycle tour across Asia have a circular format.|~|View of three male ferry passengers in transit. The man in the center wears a turban, the man on the far left wears a cap and the man in the middle wears a fez.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.

Title: Two clerks in front of the Henry Gaze & Sons Universal Travel Office, Turkey, 1895
Description.note: This photograph was most probably taken in 1895, when William Sachtleben was in Turkey to investigate the disappearance of cyclist Frank Lenz who had last been seen near Erzurum. Sachtleben's 1891 photographs of his bicycle tour across Asia have a circular format.|~|Photograph of 2 clerks, one tipping his cap, standing on either side of the entrance to the Henry Gaze & Sons Universal Travel Office. According to the signage, the company arranged travel to Egypt, the Holy Land, India, China, Japan, Australia and America. To the left are plants in small terracotta pots on a stone block. Name.subject: Sachtleben, William Lewis
Title: List of photographs of "Broussa" by William Sachtleben taken during his trip to Turkey to search for the missing cyclist Frank Lenz, 1895
Description.note: William Sachtleben was in Turkey in 1895 to investigate the disappearance of cyclist Frank Lenz who had last been seen near Erzurum. Notes accompanying negatives indicate that during this trip, Sachtleben was in Bursa and travelled from Trabzon to Erzurum.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Text: 1. the ancient column used as a corner stone at a turn in the road. Taken near the castle hill on soest slope. 2. views of the old walls, on the west. 3. Southwest taken frm across the ravine. 4. A Turkish maid who was not afraid. 5. A corner of the old fortress near gate. 6. A gendarme whose photo he wished [...] have taken very badly. [7.] [...] young Turks whose picture I too[k] [...]. [8.] An old entrance to walls on south side of Broussa. 9. A view of southern walls looking East. 10. M. Joachim Violet, a Gent. who went with Stevens to the Vali in  L[...] 11. A Broussa coachman rushing up to me for a job.

Title: William Sachtleben and Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr. pose with their bicycles, a seated wman and 2 men, Asia, 1891
Description.note: Photograph of William Sachtleben and Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr. posing with their bicycles with a seated woman wearing a striped skirt, and 2 men standing behind the group. The porch of a wooden building is visible on the left and there appears to be a road behind t hem. In another photograph Sachtleben poses in the same outfit at a telegraph office (image ark no. 21198/zz002j5dfg).|~|Photograph taken during William Lewis Sachtleben's bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.
Description.fundingNote: Access to this collection is generously supported by Arcadia funds.
Relation.isPartOf: Sachtleben (William Lewis) Papers. Department of Special Collections, Charles E. Young Research Library, UCLA.
Description.caption: Handwritten on negative: 13080 / 2

Title: Annotated sleeve for a negative of the gate to the Street of the Tombs in Athens taken by William Sachtleben, 1891
Description.note: William Lewis Sachtleben stayed in Athens before embarking on a bicycle journey across Asia with Thomas Gaskell Allen Jr.

Description.caption: Text: Jan. 15, 1891. No. 40 [or 46]. The modern gate to the enclosure of the Street of Tombs, the Wall of Themistocles and the Dipylon. The main entrance.
